                                         boolean append,
                                         java.security.cert.X509Certificate... certificates)
                                  throws java.lang.NullPointerException,
                                         java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                                         java.lang.SecurityException,
                                         java.io.IOException,
                                         CertificateLtException
        Writes the encoded form (ASN.1 DER) of the certificates to the file filename.
        Parameters:
        filename - a pathname string
        append - if true, then bytes will be written to the end of the file rather than the beginning
        certificates -
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the filename argument is null
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - If the file exists but is a directory rather than a regular file, does not exist but cannot be created, or cannot be opened for any other reason
        java.io.IOException - If an I/O error occurred
        java.lang.SecurityException - If a security manager exists and its checkRead method does not permit verification of the existence of the named directory and all necessary parent directories; or if the checkWrite method does not permit the named directory and all necessary parent directories to be created; or if a security manager exists and its checkWrite method denies write access to the file
        CertificateLtException -
        +Cause CertificateEncodingException if an encoding error occurs

      • readX509Certificate

        public static java.security.cert.X509Certificate readX509Certificate(java.lang.String filename)
                                                              throws java.lang.NullPointerException,
                                                                     java.lang.SecurityException,
                                                                     java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                                                                     CertificateLtException
        Generates a certificate object and initialises it with the data read from the file filename.
        This method uses CertificateFactory.

        The certificate provided in is must be DER-encoded and may be supplied in binary or printable (Base64) encoding. If the certificate is provided in Base64 encoding, it must be bounded at the beginning by -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----, and must be bounded at the end by -----END CERTIFICATE-----.

        If the data in the file does not contain an inherent end-of-certificate marker (other than EOF) and there is trailing data after the certificate is parsed, a CertificateException is thrown.
        Parameters:
        filename - a pathname string with the X509 certificate data
        Returns:
        the X509 certificate object initialised with the data from the file
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the filename argument is null
        java.lang.SecurityException - If a security manager exists and its checkRead method denies read access to the file
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - If the file does not exist, is a directory rather than a regular file, or for some other reason cannot be opened for reading
        CertificateLtException -
        +Cause CertificateException if it's type is not X.509 or a CertificateFactorySpi implementation for the specified algorithm is not available from the specified provider or on parsing errors
        +Cause NoSuchProviderException If the specified provider is not registered in the security provider list

      • readX509Certificate

        public static java.security.cert.X509Certificate readX509Certificate(java.io.InputStream is)
                                                              throws CertificateLtException
        Generates a certificate object and initialises it with the data read from the input stream is.
        This method uses CertificateFactory.

        The certificate provided in is must be DER-encoded and may be supplied in binary or printable (Base64) encoding. If the certificate is provided in Base64 encoding, it must be bounded at the beginning by -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----, and must be bounded at the end by -----END CERTIFICATE-----.

        Note that if the given input stream does not support mark and reset, this method will consume the entire input stream. Otherwise, each call to this method consumes one certificate and the read position of the input stream is positioned to the next available byte after the inherent end-of-certificate marker. If the data in the input stream does not contain an inherent end-of-certificate marker (other than EOF) and there is trailing data after the certificate is parsed, a CertificateException is thrown.
        Parameters:
        is - an input stream with the X509 certificate data
        Returns:
        the X509 certificate object initialised with the data from the input stream
        Throws:
        CertificateLtException -
        +Cause CertificateException if it's type is not X.509 or a CertificateFactorySpi implementation for the specified algorithm is not available from the specified provider or on parsing errors
        +Cause NoSuchProviderException If the specified provider is not registered in the security provider list

      • readX509Certificates

        public static java.security.cert.X509Certificate[] readX509Certificates(java.lang.String filename)
                                                                 throws java.lang.NullPointerException,
                                                                        java.lang.SecurityException,
                                                                        java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                                                                        CertificateLtException
        Returns an array of the X509 certificates read from the given file filename.
        This method uses CertificateFactory.

        The filename may contain a sequence of DER-encoded certificates in the formats described for generateCertificate. In addition, filename may contain a PKCS#7 certificate chain. This is a PKCS#7 SignedData object, with the only significant field being certificates. In particular, the signature and the contents are ignored. This format allows multiple certificates to be downloaded at once. If no certificates are present, an empty collection is returned.
        Parameters:
        filename - a pathname string with the X509 certificates data
        Returns:
        an array of java.security.cert.X509Certificate objects initialised with the data from the file
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the filename argument is null
        java.lang.SecurityException - If a security manager exists and its checkRead method denies read access to the file
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - If the file does not exist, is a directory rather than a regular file, or for some other reason cannot be opened for reading
        CertificateLtException -
        +Cause CertificateException if any of the certificate is not a X.509 type or a CertificateFactorySpi implementation for the specified algorithm is not available from the specified provider or on parsing errors
        +Cause NoSuchProviderException If the specified provider is not registered in the security provider list

      • readX509Certificates

        public static java.security.cert.X509Certificate[] readX509Certificates(java.io.InputStream is)
                                                                 throws CertificateLtException
        Returns an array of the X509 certificates read from the given input stream is.
        This method uses CertificateFactory.

        The is may contain a sequence of DER-encoded certificates in the formats described for generateCertificate. In addition, is may contain a PKCS#7 certificate chain. This is a PKCS#7 SignedData object, with the only significant field being certificates. In particular, the signature and the contents are ignored. This format allows multiple certificates to be downloaded at once. If no certificates are present, an empty collection is returned.

        Note that if the given input stream does not support mark and reset, this method will consume the entire input stream.
        Parameters:
        is - the input stream with the X509 certificates
        Returns:
        an array of java.security.cert.X509Certificate objects initialised with the data from the input stream
        Throws:
        CertificateLtException -
        +Cause CertificateException if any of the certificate is not a X.509 type or a CertificateFactorySpi implementation for the specified algorithm is not available from the specified provider or on parsing errors
        +Cause NoSuchProviderException If the specified provider is not registered in the security provider list

      • readPKCS10CertificationRequestPEM

        public static PKCS10CertificationRequest readPKCS10CertificationRequestPEM(java.lang.String filename,
                                                                           java.lang.String charset)
                                                                    throws java.lang.NullPointerException,
                                                                           java.lang.SecurityException,
                                                                           java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException,
                                                                           java.io.FileNotFoundException,
                                                                           java.io.IOException,
                                                                           CertificationRequestLtException
        Reads the certification request in PEM format from the file filename.
        Parameters:
        filename - a pathname string
        charset - the name of a supported charset
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the filename argument is null
        java.lang.SecurityException - If a security manager exists and its checkRead method denies read access to the file
        java.io.FileNotFoundException - If the file does not exist, is a directory rather than a regular file, or for some other reason cannot be opened for reading
        java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException - if the named charset is not supported
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurred
        CertificationRequestLtException - if the certification request in the input stream is not of type PKCS10CertificationRequest
